title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the profit-maximizing quantity as 4 units and/or does not explain that the 4th unit is the last unit where the marginal revenue ($120) is greater than the marginal cost ($100); the firm will not produce the 5th unit because the marginal cost of producing it ($150) is greater than the marginal revenue earned ($120).

The response identifies the profit-maximizing quantity as 4 units and explains that the 4th unit is the last unit where the marginal revenue ($120) is greater than the marginal cost ($100); the firm will not produce the 5th unit because the marginal cost of producing it ($150) is greater than the marginal revenue earned ($120).

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the number of firms in the industry will increase and/or does not explain that positive economic profit will attract new firms to enter the industry.
The response states that the number of firms in the industry will increase and explains that positive economic profit will attract new firms to enter the industry.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the market price will decrease and/or does not explain that with the entry of firms, the market supply will increase, causing the price to decrease.
The response states that the market price will decrease and explains that with the entry of firms, the market supply will increase, causing the price to decrease.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the demand for shoes will increase and/or does not explain that the negative cross-price elasticity of demand for shoes with respect to the price of Good X means that the goods are complements; therefore, a decrease in the price of Good X will lead to an increase in the demand for shoes.

The response states that that the demand for shoes will increase and explains that the negative cross-price elasticity of demand for shoes with respect to the price of Good X means that the goods are complements; therefore, a decrease in the price of Good X will lead to an increase in the demand for shoes.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does none of the following:

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good X will stay the same in the short run and explains that a change in fixed cost does not affect the marginal cost.

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good X will decrease and explains that an increase in the market wage will increase the wage the firm pays its workers because the firm is a wage-taker in a perfectly competitive market; wages are a variable cost, so an increase in the wage will shift the marginal cost curve upward at each quantity so that marginal cost will intersect marginal revenue at a lower quantity.

The response does one of the following:

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good X will stay the same in the short run and explains that a change in fixed cost does not affect the marginal cost.

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good X will decrease and explains that an increase in the market wage will increase the wage the firm pays its workers because the firm is a wage-taker in a perfectly competitive market; wages are a variable cost, so an increase in the wage will shift the marginal cost curve upward at each quantity so that marginal cost will intersect marginal revenue at a lower quantity.

The response does both of the following:

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good X will stay the same in the short run and explains that a change in fixed cost does not affect the marginal cost.

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good X will decrease and explains that an increase in the market wage will increase the wage the firm pays its workers because the firm is a wage-taker in a perfectly competitive market; wages are a variable cost, so an increase in the wage will shift the marginal cost curve upward at each quantity so that marginal cost will intersect marginal revenue at a lower quantity.
